meta.notes: Site data for Lenny's Adventure Guide. Edit this file to add/remove sites or update fees.

norcal.name: Northern California
norcal.intro: From coastal redwoods to Sierra peaks, these are the sites that match your interests best. Every site below accepts your Lifetime Senior Pass.

startHere.reason: Outstanding fishing, Gold Rush history, and your pass saves $25. Just 2.5 hours from Sacramento ‚Äî a perfect spring day trip.

socal.name: Central & Southern California
socal.intro: A weekend drive south from Sacramento opens up desert wonders, island adventures, and some of the most moving American history sites in the West.

startHere.reason: One of America's most powerful WWII sites ‚Äî the internment camp where 10,000 Japanese Americans were confined. 4.5 hours from Sacramento, and your pass saves $15.

newengland.name: New England
newengland.intro: New England combines American history with rugged coastlines and mountain forests. The concentration of Revolutionary War, industrial, and maritime sites here is unmatched.

startHere.reason: You already know this one ‚Äî and the 5-mile paved Battle Road Trail is perfect for a February bike ride. Free entry, always.

nationwide.name: Rest of USA
nationwide.intro: Your pass works everywhere ‚Äî these are 75 of the best sites across the rest of the country, curated for fishing, biking, history, and easy access.

california.details: Standard annual sport fishing license (~$55 for residents). No general senior discount ‚Äî the reduced fee (~$8) is only for low-income seniors on SSI/CAPI.
california.tip: Purchase online at wildlife.ca.gov or at sporting goods stores. Remember to buy any required report cards for salmon, steelhead, or sturgeon.

massachusetts.details: FREE for residents age 70+ (you qualify!). Still need to register and obtain the license. A $5 Wildlands Conservation Stamp is added to your first license each year.
massachusetts.tip: Even though it's free, you must carry the license while fishing.

maine.details: One-time $8 lifetime license for residents age 65+. Covers fishing, hunting, and more ‚Äî an incredible deal.
maine.tip: Apply at maine.gov/ifw. This is one of the best senior fishing deals in the country.

newhampshire.details: Discounted senior freshwater license for residents born in/after 1948 who are 68+. Free permanent license for residents born in/before 1947.
newhampshire.tip: NH saltwater license is separate ‚Äî but it's reciprocal with MA and ME coastal waters.

vermont.details: Lifetime license available for residents age 66+ ($60 one-time). Annual licenses also available.
vermont.tip: VT and NH have reciprocal agreements for the Connecticut River.

connecticut.tip: CT marine license is reciprocal with ME, MA, RI, and NY coastal waters.

sites.name: Yosemite National Park
sites.description: World Heritage Site with Half Dome, El Capitan, and iconic waterfalls.

highlights.fishing: Trout fishing in the Merced and Tuolumne rivers. Mirror Lake offers peaceful shoreline fishing.
highlights.easy: Glacier Point paved viewpoint; valley shuttle accessible; Mirror Lake trail partially paved.

seasonal.note: Tioga Road closed Nov‚ÄìMay. Valley accessible year-round.

sites.name: Redwood National Park
sites.description: Home to Earth's tallest trees ‚Äî coast redwoods exceeding 380 feet.

highlights.fishing: Steelhead and salmon in Redwood Creek and Smith River.
highlights.easy: Big Tree Trail: paved 0.3-mi loop. Newton B. Drury Parkway: 10-mi drive through old-growth.

seasonal.note: Drier months (Jun‚ÄìSep) best for trails. Elk viewing peaks in fall.

sites.name: Lassen Volcanic NP
sites.description: The only place on Earth with all four volcano types. Active mud pots and fumaroles.

highlights.fishing: Manzanita Lake and Summit Lake ‚Äî quiet trout fishing with mountain reflections.
highlights.easy: Sulphur Works boardwalk from car; 30-mile scenic drive with pullouts.

seasonal.note: Main park road closed by snow Nov‚ÄìMay. Manzanita Lake area may open earlier.

sites.name: Point Reyes Nat'l Seashore
sites.description: Dramatic coastal cliffs on the San Andreas Fault with tule elk herds.

highlights.fishing: Quiet kayak fishing in Tomales Bay ‚Äî bass, halibut, and perch.
highlights.biking: Fire roads with sweeping Pacific views. Relatively flat terrain for road bikes.
highlights.history: Historic Point Reyes Lighthouse and Coast Miwok village sites.
highlights.easy: Earthquake Trail: 0.7-mile fully paved and level.

seasonal.note: Whale watching best Jan‚ÄìApr. Elk rut in Sep. Foggy in summer.

sites.name: Muir Woods Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Old-growth coast redwoods 600‚Äì1,200 years old, closest grove to San Francisco.

highlights.history: Site of preliminary UN Charter meetings in 1945.
highlights.easy: Main loop: 0.5-mile accessible boardwalk through ancient redwoods.

seasonal.note: Reservation required for parking and shuttle. Weekday mornings are quietest.

sites.name: Golden Gate NRA
sites.description: 19 ecosystems spanning SF Bay Area ‚Äî Alcatraz, Presidio, Marin Headlands.

highlights.biking: Extensive paved bike paths through the Presidio and along the Bay.
highlights.history: Alcatraz prison, Fort Point (Civil War), Presidio from 1776, Nike missile sites.
highlights.easy: Crissy Field: fully paved with Bay views.

seasonal.note: Alcatraz sells out weeks ahead ‚Äî book early. Sept‚ÄìOct warmest weather.

sites.name: Whiskeytown NRA
sites.description: Crystal-clear lake with excellent fishing and Gold Rush history near Redding.

highlights.fishing: Outstanding bass, trout, and kokanee salmon. Superb boat fishing.
highlights.biking: Over 20 miles of mountain bike trails.
highlights.history: Camden House and Tower House ‚Äî Gold Rush era.

seasonal.note: Spring fishing is excellent. Summer gets hot (100¬∞F+). Fall is ideal.

sites.name: John Muir NHS
sites.description: Home of the 'Father of National Parks' in Martinez.

highlights.history: Tour the Victorian home and fruit ranch of John Muir.
highlights.easy: Grounds and first floor fully accessible.

seasonal.note: Open Wed‚ÄìSun. Check nps.gov for tour times.

sites.name: Rosie the Riveter NHP
sites.description: Honors WWII home front workers in Richmond.

highlights.history: WWII ‚Äî stories of women and minorities who powered the war effort.
highlights.easy: Fully accessible visitor center with excellent exhibits.

seasonal.note: Visitor center open daily. SS Red Oak Victory ship tours available.

sites.name: Sacramento NWR
sites.description: Winter home to 600,000+ ducks and 200,000+ geese.

highlights.easy: 6-mile auto tour with accessible observation decks.

seasonal.note: Peak waterfowl season is winter. You're in the perfect window right now!

sites.name: Fort Ord Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Former military base with 86 miles of trails in Monterey County.

highlights.biking: Extensive mountain biking network ‚Äî 86 miles of trails.

seasonal.note: Mild coastal climate. Spring wildflowers are spectacular.

sites.name: Eagle Lake (Lassen NF)
sites.description: California's second-largest natural lake with accessible facilities.

highlights.fishing: Renowned Eagle Lake trout ‚Äî excellent boat fishing on calm waters.
highlights.easy: Accessible boat launch and lakeside facilities.

seasonal.note: Eagle Lake trout fishing peaks in late spring and fall.

sites.name: Hat Creek (Lassen NF)
sites.description: World-renowned fly fishing in the shadow of Lassen Peak.

highlights.fishing: Wild trout section ‚Äî world-class fly fishing in pristine mountain stream.

seasonal.note: Best fly fishing is late spring through early fall.

sites.name: Tahoe NF / Downieville
sites.description: Historic Donner Pass, Sierra Buttes, world-class trails.

highlights.biking: Downieville Downhill and great road cycling on forest roads.
highlights.fishing: Truckee River, Yuba River, and alpine lakes.

seasonal.note: Snow closes higher elevations in winter. Downieville trails best Jun‚ÄìOct.

sites.name: Don Edwards SF Bay NWR
sites.description: Urban refuge with 30 miles of trails along San Francisco Bay.

highlights.biking: Paved multi-use trails for easy road biking with bay views.
highlights.easy: Flat, paved paths accessible for all abilities.

seasonal.note: Migratory bird season peaks Oct‚ÄìApr.

sites.name: Lava Beds Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Over 800 lava tube caves ‚Äî North America's largest concentration.

highlights.history: Captain Jack's Stronghold: 1872‚Äì73 Modoc War battlefields and rock art.

seasonal.note: Cave temperature is constant 55¬∞F year-round. Bring a jacket underground.

sites.name: Tule Lake Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Site of the largest WWII Japanese American internment camp.

highlights.history: One of America's most significant WWII civil rights sites.

seasonal.note: Combine with Lava Beds ‚Äî they're adjacent.

sites.name: Frazier Falls (Plumas NF)
sites.description: Spectacular 178-foot waterfall in the Lost Sierra.

highlights.easy: 1-mile fully paved trail to waterfall viewpoint.

seasonal.note: Best waterfall flow in late spring / early summer.

sites.name: Humboldt Bay NWR
sites.description: Coastal refuge along Highway 101 with excellent birdwatching.

highlights.easy: Wheelchair-accessible deck, boardwalk, and observation platform.

seasonal.note: Peak shorebird migration in spring and fall.

sites.name: Lower Klamath NWR
sites.description: Nation's first waterfowl refuge (est. 1908 by Teddy Roosevelt).

highlights.easy: Auto tour through one of the largest bald eagle concentrations in the lower 48.

seasonal.note: Peak bald eagle season is winter.

sites.name: Port Chicago Memorial
sites.description: Site of worst home front disaster of WWII.

highlights.history: 1944 explosion killed 320 and sparked civil rights movement in the Navy.

seasonal.note: Reservation required ‚Äî access is through a military base. Plan ahead.

sites.name: Pinnacles National Park
sites.description: Dramatic volcanic spires, talus caves, and California condors.

highlights.easy: Balconies Cave and Bear Gulch Cave are walkable. Condor viewing from easy trails.

seasonal.note: Summer is brutally hot (100¬∞F+). Spring wildflowers are spectacular.

sites.name: Sequoia & Kings Canyon NP
sites.description: Home to General Sherman ‚Äî Earth's largest living tree ‚Äî and the deepest canyon in the US.

highlights.fishing: Kaweah River and high-country lakes for trout in pristine Sierra settings.
highlights.easy: Giant Forest paved trails to General Sherman and Moro Rock overlook. Scenic drives throughout.

seasonal.note: Generals Highway may close in winter. Giant Forest accessible most of the year.

sites.name: Manzanar NHS
sites.description: WWII Japanese American internment camp where 10,000+ were confined 1942‚Äì45.

highlights.history: Restored barracks, mess hall, guard tower, and deeply moving interpretive exhibits. One of the most important civil rights sites in America.
highlights.easy: Visitor center fully accessible. 3.2-mile auto tour through the camp grounds.

seasonal.note: Spring and fall are mild. Summer is hot. Winter can be cold but uncrowded.

sites.name: Death Valley NP
sites.description: Hottest, driest, lowest ‚Äî extremes define this otherworldly landscape.

highlights.history: Scotty's Castle, Harmony Borax Works, ghost towns.
highlights.easy: Badwater Basin, Artist's Drive, Zabriskie Point all accessible from car.

seasonal.note: Visit in winter or spring. Summer temperatures exceed 120¬∞F ‚Äî dangerous.

sites.name: Joshua Tree NP
sites.description: Where Mojave and Colorado deserts meet ‚Äî iconic twisted trees and boulder landscapes.

highlights.easy: Park Boulevard scenic drive with dozens of pullouts. Skull Rock and Arch Rock short walks.

seasonal.note: Spring wildflower bloom (Mar‚ÄìApr) can be extraordinary. Avoid summer heat.

sites.name: Channel Islands NP
sites.description: Five remote islands off the coast ‚Äî California's Gal√°pagos. Accessible only by boat.

highlights.fishing: Outstanding ocean fishing on the boat ride over and around the islands. Kelp forests with incredible marine life.
highlights.easy: Visitor center in Ventura is fully accessible. Island Access requires boat ‚Äî moderate physical ability.

seasonal.note: Whale watching Dec‚ÄìApr. Clearest water Jul‚ÄìOct. Book Island Packers boat early.

sites.name: Santa Monica Mountains NRA
sites.description: Mediterranean landscape between LA and the Pacific ‚Äî the world's largest urban national park.

highlights.biking: Backbone Trail and Mulholland Drive offer road and mountain biking with ocean views.
highlights.easy: Paramount Ranch (former movie set), Satwiwa Cultural Center, accessible visitor areas.

seasonal.note: Wildflower season Feb‚ÄìMay. Summer can be hot inland.

sites.name: C√©sar E. Ch√°vez NM
sites.description: Headquarters of the United Farm Workers ‚Äî where C√©sar Ch√°vez lived and is buried.

highlights.history: The labor movement that changed American agriculture. Ch√°vez's office preserved as it was. A powerful piece of modern American history.
highlights.easy: Visitor center and memorial garden fully accessible.

seasonal.note: Open Mon‚ÄìSat. Located in Keene, CA between Bakersfield and LA.

sites.name: Devils Postpile NM
sites.description: Remarkable columnar basalt formation and Rainbow Falls near Mammoth Lakes.

highlights.fishing: Middle Fork San Joaquin River for trout in a spectacular canyon setting.
highlights.easy: Short trail from shuttle stop to the Postpile. Rainbow Falls trail is 2.5 mi round trip.

seasonal.note: Only accessible mid-June to October. Mandatory shuttle in summer.

sites.name: Mojave National Preserve
sites.description: 1.6 million acres of desert beauty ‚Äî singing dunes, lava flows, and Joshua tree forests.

highlights.history: Kelso Depot: beautifully restored 1924 Union Pacific railroad station, now the visitor center.
highlights.easy: Kelso Dunes and Hole-in-the-Wall accessible by car. Scenic drives through vast open desert.

seasonal.note: Avoid summer. Spring wildflowers can be extraordinary.

sites.name: Cabrillo Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Where European exploration of the West Coast began ‚Äî stunning views of San Diego Bay.

highlights.history: Juan Rodr√≠guez Cabrillo landed here in 1542. Old Point Loma Lighthouse (1855). WWII coastal defense exhibits.
highlights.easy: Bayside Trail is paved. Tide pools accessible at low tide. All viewpoints accessible.

seasonal.note: Whale watching Dec‚ÄìMar from the overlook. Tide pools best at low tide ‚Äî check schedules.

sites.name: Acadia National Park
sites.description: Rugged coastline, granite peaks, and 45+ miles of historic carriage roads.

highlights.fishing: Jordan Pond and Eagle Lake ‚Äî quiet freshwater fishing. Ocean fishing off Bass Harbor.
highlights.biking: 45+ mi crushed stone carriage roads. Gentle grades, no cars ‚Äî built by Rockefeller Jr.
highlights.easy: Many carriage roads accommodate wheelchairs; accessible visitor centers.

seasonal.note: Fall foliage (late Sep‚Äìmid Oct) is spectacular. Carriage roads open Apr‚ÄìNov.

sites.name: Cape Cod Nat'l Seashore
sites.description: 40 miles of pristine sandy beaches, marshes, ponds, and lighthouses.

highlights.fishing: Kettle ponds for secluded freshwater fishing. Surf fishing for striped bass.
highlights.biking: Province Lands Trail (5.5 mi paved), Nauset Trail, Head of the Meadow.
highlights.history: Pilgrim history, maritime heritage, Marconi wireless station.
highlights.easy: Buttonbush Trail fully accessible; beach wheelchairs available.

seasonal.note: Surf fishing for stripers peaks Sep‚ÄìOct. Summer beaches are crowded ‚Äî go early.

sites.name: White Mountain NF
sites.description: 800,000 acres with the Northeast's highest peaks including Mt. Washington.

highlights.fishing: Outstanding mountain streams and lakes for trout.
highlights.biking: Forest roads ideal for road cycling through mountain scenery.

seasonal.note: Fall foliage is world-class. Kancamagus Highway scenic drive peaks late Sep.

sites.name: Green Mountain NF
sites.description: 400,000 acres of Vermont's mountain forests with 900 miles of trails.

highlights.fishing: Excellent trout streams and mountain ponds.
highlights.biking: Robert Frost Trail and forest road cycling.

seasonal.note: Maple syrup season (Feb‚ÄìMar) is a fun side trip. Fall colors peak early Oct.

sites.name: Boston NHP
sites.description: Freedom Trail ‚Äî Faneuil Hall, Old North Church, Bunker Hill, USS Constitution.

highlights.history: Revolutionary War history ‚Äî walk through America's founding.
highlights.easy: Urban setting with excellent accessibility.

seasonal.note: Spring and fall are ideal. USS Constitution tours available daily.

sites.name: Minute Man NHP
sites.description: Where the American Revolution began ‚Äî April 19, 1775.

highlights.history: 'The shot heard round the world.' Battle Road traces the first clashes.
highlights.biking: 5 mi paved, flat ‚Äî perfect for road bikes.
highlights.easy: Battle Road Trail: fully paved, flat, accessible.

seasonal.note: Patriots' Day (3rd Mon in April) has reenactments. Trail is great for winter biking too.

sites.name: Adams NHP
sites.description: Birthplaces and homes of Presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams.

highlights.history: Tour the homes of two presidents ‚Äî father and son.

seasonal.note: Tours run seasonally. Check nps.gov for current schedule.

sites.name: Salem Maritime NHS
sites.description: America's first National Historic Site (1938) ‚Äî 600 years of maritime history.

highlights.history: 12 historic buildings, wharves, replica ship. Maritime golden age.
highlights.easy: Waterfront areas mostly accessible.

seasonal.note: Salem in October has Halloween festivities but huge crowds.

sites.name: Lowell NHP
sites.description: Birthplace of America's Industrial Revolution.

highlights.history: Restored 19th-century mill buildings and canal system.
highlights.easy: Excellent urban accessibility.

seasonal.note: Boat tours on the canals run summer months. Folk Festival in July.

sites.name: Saint-Gaudens NHP
sites.description: Home and studios of America's foremost sculptor.

highlights.history: Saint-Gaudens sculpted the Lincoln, Sherman, and Shaw memorials.
highlights.easy: Main house and gardens accessible.

seasonal.note: Grounds open year-round; buildings and exhibits seasonal.

sites.name: Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller NHP
sites.description: Only NPS site focused on conservation history.

highlights.history: 150 years of stewardship from Marsh to the Rockefellers.
highlights.biking: Carriage roads for gentle cycling.

seasonal.note: Mansion tours summer only. Grounds and trails year-round.

sites.name: Parker River NWR
sites.description: Plum Island barrier beach ‚Äî premier fishing destination.

highlights.fishing: Surf fishing ‚Äî striped bass, bluefish, flounder.
highlights.biking: Refuge Road open to cycling along the coast.

seasonal.note: Surf fishing peaks Sep‚ÄìOct. Beach closes partially for nesting piping plovers Apr‚ÄìAug.

sites.name: New Bedford Whaling NHP
sites.description: America's whaling capital at its 19th-century peak.

highlights.history: Melville set Moby-Dick here ‚Äî the city that lit the world's lamps.

seasonal.note: Whaling Museum is separate (admission fee). NHP sites are free.

sites.name: Roger Williams Memorial
sites.description: Honors Rhode Island's founder and pioneer of religious freedom.

highlights.history: Roger Williams championed separation of church and state.
highlights.easy: Accessible park.

seasonal.note: Small site ‚Äî combine with other Providence attractions.

sites.name: Weir Farm NHP
sites.description: Only NPS site dedicated to American painting.

highlights.history: Studios of American Impressionist J. Alden Weir.

seasonal.note: Summer painting workshops. Fall colors are a natural canvas.

sites.name: Assabet River NWR
sites.description: Former military base converted to wildlife refuge.

highlights.biking: 15+ miles of trails ‚Äî flat and easy.

seasonal.note: Some trails may be muddy in spring. Great fall foliage riding.

sites.name: Great Meadows NWR
sites.description: Freshwater wetlands near Concord with 220+ bird species.

highlights.easy: Dike trails flat and accessible ‚Äî peaceful birdwatching.

seasonal.note: Spring migration is spectacular. Near Walden Pond and Concord historic sites.

sites.name: Rachel Carson NWR
sites.description: 5,600+ acres of salt marshes along southern Maine coast.

highlights.easy: 1-mile Carson Trail with accessible sections.

seasonal.note: Named for the author of Silent Spring. Combines well with a Maine coast trip.

sites.name: Blackstone River Valley NHP
sites.description: America's Industrial Revolution began in this river valley.

highlights.history: Slater Mill and the birth of American industry.
highlights.biking: Blackstone Bikeway connects historic sites.

seasonal.note: Bikeway is a great year-round ride. Mill tours seasonal.

sites.name: Yellowstone NP
sites.description: America's first national park ‚Äî geysers, hot springs, and abundant wildlife.

highlights.fishing: World-class fly fishing in the Yellowstone, Madison, and Firehole rivers.
highlights.easy: Old Faithful boardwalks, Grand Prismatic overlook, and scenic drives.

seasonal.note: Most roads closed Nov‚ÄìApr. Old Faithful area accessible year-round.

sites.name: Grand Teton NP
sites.description: Dramatic Teton Range rising 7,000 feet above the valley floor.

highlights.fishing: Jenny Lake and the Snake River ‚Äî outstanding trout fishing.
highlights.biking: 20+ miles of paved multi-use pathway through the park.
highlights.easy: Jenny Lake boat shuttle; many paved viewpoints.

seasonal.note: Teton Park Road closed Nov‚ÄìApr. Combine with Yellowstone.

sites.name: Glacier NP
sites.description: Crown of the Continent ‚Äî 130+ named lakes, 25 glaciers.

highlights.fishing: Lake McDonald, St. Mary Lake for cutthroat trout.
highlights.easy: Going-to-the-Sun Road: 50-mile scenic drive with accessible overlooks.

seasonal.note: Going-to-the-Sun Road opens mid-June to mid-October. Vehicle reservations required.

sites.name: Olympic NP
sites.description: Temperate rainforest, alpine peaks, and rugged Pacific coast.

highlights.fishing: Lake Crescent, Hoh River, Sol Duc River for trout and salmon.
highlights.easy: Hall of Mosses: 0.8-mi trail. Hurricane Ridge: paved trails with mountain views.

seasonal.note: Rain is heavy Oct‚ÄìMay. Rainforest is lush year-round.

sites.name: Mount Rainier NP
sites.description: Iconic volcanic peak with glaciers and wildflower meadows.

highlights.easy: Paradise area: paved trails. Sunrise has accessible overlooks.

seasonal.note: Wildflower peak is late July. Paradise road open year-round; other roads seasonal.

sites.name: Crater Lake NP
sites.description: Deepest lake in the US ‚Äî stunning sapphire blue water in a volcanic caldera.

highlights.fishing: Rainbow trout and kokanee ‚Äî no license required in the lake.
highlights.easy: 33-mile Rim Drive with 30+ scenic overlooks.

seasonal.note: Rim Drive opens late June. North entrance may not open until July.

sites.name: Rocky Mountain NP
sites.description: Alpine tundra, peaks, and pristine lakes above 12,000 feet.

highlights.fishing: Sprague Lake, Bear Lake, Big Thompson River for trout.
highlights.easy: Trail Ridge Road: highest paved road in any NP (12,183 ft). Bear Lake paved.

seasonal.note: Trail Ridge Road closed mid-Oct to Memorial Day. Timed entry required in summer.

sites.name: Hawaii Volcanoes NP
sites.description: Two active volcanoes ‚Äî Kƒ´lauea and Mauna Loa.

highlights.easy: Crater Rim Drive with accessible overlooks; Devastation Trail is paved boardwalk.

seasonal.note: Volcanic activity varies ‚Äî check nps.gov for current eruption status.

sites.name: Denali NP
sites.description: Six million acres surrounding North America's tallest peak.

highlights.fishing: Horseshoe Lake and area rivers for grayling and trout.
highlights.easy: Park bus tours: see wildlife and Denali from your seat.

seasonal.note: Park road beyond Mile 15 is bus-access only. Book bus tours well in advance.

sites.name: Great Sand Dunes NP
sites.description: Tallest sand dunes in North America ‚Äî 750 feet.

highlights.easy: Walk from parking lot onto dunes. Accessible boardwalk to dune field.

seasonal.note: Medano Creek flows late May‚Äìearly July ‚Äî a unique experience.

sites.name: Grand Canyon NP
sites.description: 277 miles of layered rock revealing two billion years of Earth's history.

highlights.history: Ancestral Puebloan sites, Mary Colter architecture, Desert View Watchtower.
highlights.easy: South Rim Trail: 13 mi paved. Shuttle accessible. All overlooks paved.

seasonal.note: South Rim open year-round. North Rim closes mid-Oct to mid-May.

sites.name: Zion NP
sites.description: Towering sandstone cliffs and narrow slot canyons.

highlights.biking: Pa'rus Trail: 3.5 mi paved, flat, bikes allowed, along the Virgin River.
highlights.easy: Shuttle scenic drive; Riverside Walk partially paved.

seasonal.note: Summer is very hot and crowded. Spring and fall are ideal.

sites.name: Bryce Canyon NP
sites.description: Largest concentration of hoodoos on Earth ‚Äî otherworldly red rock spires.

highlights.easy: Rim Trail between Sunset and Sunrise Points is paved and mostly level.

seasonal.note: At 8,000 ft, snow is possible Oct‚ÄìMay. Stargazing is extraordinary.

sites.name: Arches NP
sites.description: Over 2,000 natural stone arches in southeastern Utah.

highlights.easy: Scenic drive; many arches visible from car; short paved viewpoint trails.

seasonal.note: Timed entry required Apr‚ÄìOct. Book at recreation.gov.

sites.name: Carlsbad Caverns NP
sites.description: Massive underground chambers with spectacular formations.

highlights.easy: Elevator into Big Room; 1.25 mi paved underground trail.

seasonal.note: Cave is 56¬∞F always. Bat flight program May‚ÄìOct at sunset.

sites.name: White Sands NP
sites.description: 275 square miles of brilliant white gypsum dunes.

highlights.easy: 8-mi scenic drive. Interdune Boardwalk wheelchair accessible.

seasonal.note: Sunset is magical. Check for missile range closures (1‚Äì2 hrs, sporadic).

sites.name: Petrified Forest NP
sites.description: Petrified wood, painted desert, and ancient pueblo ruins.

highlights.history: Puerco Pueblo: Ancestral Puebloan dwelling and petroglyphs from 650 CE.
highlights.easy: 28-mile scenic drive with short paved trails at every stop.

seasonal.note: Mild fall and spring. Summer is hot but manageable with the scenic drive.

sites.name: Saguaro NP
sites.description: Giant saguaro cacti in the Sonoran Desert near Tucson.

highlights.biking: Cactus Forest Loop: 8 mi paved, popular with road cyclists.
highlights.easy: Scenic drives; Desert Discovery Nature Trail is flat and accessible.

seasonal.note: Saguaro blooms May‚ÄìJun. Avoid summer midday heat.

sites.name: Mesa Verde NP
sites.description: Spectacular 800-year-old cliff dwellings ‚Äî 600+ in the park.

highlights.history: Cliff Palace and Balcony House: apartment complexes in sandstone alcoves.
highlights.easy: Mesa Top Loop: 6-mi drive with overlooks of cliff dwellings from above.

seasonal.note: Cliff Palace tours summer only. Mesa Top Loop year-round.

sites.name: Bandelier Nat'l Monument
sites.description: Ancestral Puebloan homes carved into volcanic cliffs.

highlights.history: Cliff dwellings, cave rooms, and ceremonial kiva from the 1100s.
highlights.easy: Main Loop: 1.2 mi paved through pueblo ruins.

seasonal.note: Shuttle required in summer from White Rock. Fall is uncrowded and beautiful.

sites.name: Great Smoky Mountains NP
sites.description: America's most visited NP ‚Äî misty peaks and old-growth forest.

highlights.fishing: 700+ miles of streams. Excellent smallmouth bass and trout.
highlights.easy: Cades Cove: 11-mi scenic loop with wildlife. Sugarlands accessible trails.

seasonal.note: Fall colors peak mid-Oct. Synchronous fireflies display in late May/early Jun.

sites.name: Shenandoah NP
sites.description: Blue Ridge Mountains with the iconic 105-mile Skyline Drive.

highlights.fishing: 60+ trout streams within the park.
highlights.easy: Skyline Drive: 75 overlooks. Limberlost Trail wheelchair accessible.

seasonal.note: Fall foliage peaks mid-Oct. Skyline Drive may close in ice/snow.

sites.name: Everglades NP
sites.description: Largest subtropical wilderness ‚Äî alligators, manatees, and mangroves.

highlights.fishing: World-class backcountry: snook, tarpon, redfish.
highlights.easy: Anhinga Trail: 0.8-mi boardwalk. Shark Valley tram tour.

seasonal.note: Dry season is best. Summer is hot, buggy, and hurricane season.

sites.name: Dry Tortugas NP
sites.description: Remote island fortress 70 miles west of Key West.

highlights.fishing: Outstanding snorkeling and fishing in crystal-clear waters.
highlights.history: Fort Jefferson: massive 19th-century fort. Held Dr. Mudd after Lincoln's assassination.

seasonal.note: Ferry or seaplane from Key West. Book well in advance.

sites.name: Congaree NP
sites.description: Largest old-growth bottomland hardwood forest in the Southeast.

highlights.fishing: Canoe fishing on Cedar Creek for bass and catfish.
highlights.easy: 2.4-mile boardwalk loop ‚Äî flat and accessible.

seasonal.note: Synchronous fireflies late May. Flooding adds beauty but check conditions.

sites.name: Mammoth Cave NP
sites.description: World's longest cave system ‚Äî 420+ mapped miles underground.

highlights.fishing: Green and Nolin Rivers for bass and catfish.
highlights.easy: Accessible cave tour; Heritage Trail is paved.

seasonal.note: Cave is 54¬∞F always. Accessible tour available ‚Äî book at recreation.gov.

sites.name: Hot Springs NP
sites.description: America's oldest federal reserve ‚Äî thermal springs and Bathhouse Row.

highlights.history: Eight ornate early-1900s bathhouses, including a working 1915 bathhouse.
highlights.easy: Grand Promenade: 0.5-mi paved. Bathhouses accessible.

seasonal.note: The hot springs flow year-round. Buckstaff Bathhouse still offers baths.

sites.name: Gettysburg NMP
sites.description: Decisive Civil War battle ‚Äî July 1863. Lincoln's Gettysburg Address.

highlights.history: Turning point of the Civil War. 1,300+ monuments and markers.
highlights.biking: 40+ miles of paved battlefield roads ‚Äî excellent for cycling.
highlights.easy: Auto tour loop. Museum and Cyclorama accessible.

seasonal.note: Anniversary events in early July. Fall is beautiful and less crowded.

sites.name: Vicksburg NMP
sites.description: Pivotal 1863 siege that split the Confederacy.

highlights.history: 47-day siege gave the Union control of the Mississippi. 1,300+ monuments.
highlights.easy: 16-mile auto tour ‚Äî mostly accessible from the car.

seasonal.note: Spring and fall are mildest. USS Cairo museum is a highlight.

sites.name: Antietam Nat'l Battlefield
sites.description: Bloodiest single day in American history ‚Äî September 17, 1862.

highlights.history: 23,000 casualties in one day. Burnside Bridge and Dunker Church.
highlights.biking: 8.5-mile tour road popular with cyclists.
highlights.easy: Driving tour with accessible waysides.

seasonal.note: Anniversary commemoration in September. Dawn and dusk are especially moving.

sites.name: Manassas NBP
sites.description: Two major Civil War battles ‚Äî First and Second Bull Run.

highlights.history: Where Stonewall Jackson earned his name.
highlights.easy: Driving tour with accessible waysides.

seasonal.note: Less crowded than Gettysburg but equally important.

sites.name: Fredericksburg & Spotsylvania
sites.description: Four major Civil War battles ‚Äî 85,000 total casualties.

highlights.history: Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, Wilderness, and Spotsylvania.
highlights.easy: Driving tours with accessible stops.

seasonal.note: Stonewall Jackson's death site at Chancellorsville is deeply moving.

sites.name: Little Bighorn Battlefield
sites.description: Custer's Last Stand ‚Äî June 25, 1876.

highlights.history: Lakota, Cheyenne, and Arapaho defeated the 7th Cavalry. Markers show where soldiers fell.
highlights.easy: 4.5-mi driving tour with accessible overlooks.

seasonal.note: Anniversary reenactment in late June. Haunting at any time of year.

sites.name: Pearl Harbor NM
sites.description: USS Arizona Memorial ‚Äî December 7, 1941.

highlights.history: The attack that brought America into WWII. Arizona, Missouri, and submarine tours.
highlights.easy: Visitor center accessible; boat to memorial is wheelchair accessible.

seasonal.note: Reserve free tickets at recreation.gov well in advance. Arrive early.

sites.name: Statue of Liberty NM
sites.description: Symbol of freedom since 1886. Ellis Island next door.

highlights.history: Gift from France. Ellis Island processed 12 million immigrants.
highlights.easy: Grounds accessible; pedestal elevator. Ellis Island fully accessible.

seasonal.note: Crown access requires advance booking months ahead. Pedestal is more accessible.

sites.name: Independence NHP
sites.description: Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell ‚Äî birthplace of the nation.

highlights.history: Declaration of Independence and Constitution both signed here.
highlights.easy: Urban, all major sites accessible.

seasonal.note: Timed tickets for Independence Hall ‚Äî get early morning slots.

sites.name: Valley Forge NHP
sites.description: Washington's Continental Army winter encampment, 1777‚Äì78.

highlights.history: The winter that forged an army. Headquarters, soldier huts, monuments.
highlights.biking: 6-mile paved loop with dedicated bike lanes.
highlights.easy: Driving tour with accessible stops.

seasonal.note: Washington's birthday events in February. Fall colors are gorgeous.

sites.name: Harpers Ferry NHP
sites.description: Where rivers meet ‚Äî John Brown's 1859 raid.

highlights.history: Raid that helped spark the Civil War.
highlights.biking: C&O Canal Towpath: 185 miles of flat, packed gravel.

seasonal.note: The confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah is stunning in fall.

sites.name: Ford's Theatre NHS
sites.description: Where President Lincoln was assassinated ‚Äî April 14, 1865.

highlights.history: The theater, the presidential box, and Petersen House where Lincoln died.
highlights.easy: Fully accessible museum and theater.

seasonal.note: Free timed tickets required. Get them online at recreation.gov.

sites.name: FDR Memorial
sites.description: Four galleries tracing FDR's terms through the Depression and WWII.

highlights.history: Chronological journey through Depression, New Deal, and WWII.
highlights.easy: Entirely open-air, level, wheelchair accessible.

seasonal.note: Cherry blossom season (late Mar‚Äìearly Apr) is magical here. Best at night.

sites.name: WWII Memorial
sites.description: Honors 16 million who served and 400,000+ who died in WWII.

highlights.history: Pillars for each state. Freedom Wall: 4,048 gold stars ‚Äî one per 100 who died.
highlights.easy: Open plaza, fully accessible.

seasonal.note: Visit at dawn or dusk for the most powerful experience.

sites.name: Wright Brothers NM
sites.description: Where powered flight began ‚Äî December 17, 1903.

highlights.history: Stand where the Wright Flyer took off. Markers show all four flight distances.
highlights.easy: Flat terrain, paved paths, accessible visitor center.

seasonal.note: December 17 anniversary flight celebrations. Outer Banks beaches nearby.

sites.name: Fort Sumter NM
sites.description: Where the Civil War began ‚Äî April 12, 1861.

highlights.history: The first shots of the Civil War. Ferry from Charleston.

seasonal.note: Ferry required ‚Äî book at fort-sumter-tours.com. Anniversary events in April.

sites.name: Voyageurs NP
sites.description: Water-based park ‚Äî interconnected lakes on the Canadian border.

highlights.fishing: Walleye, northern pike, smallmouth bass ‚Äî some of the best lake fishing in America.

seasonal.note: Boat or canoe required for most of the park. Ice fishing in winter.

sites.name: Indiana Dunes NP
sites.description: 15 miles of Lake Michigan shoreline with towering sand dunes.

highlights.biking: Calumet Trail: 9.2 mi paved between communities.
highlights.easy: West Beach accessible boardwalk and short paved trails.

seasonal.note: Swimming in Lake Michigan Jun‚ÄìSep. Uncrowded in shoulder seasons.

sites.name: Theodore Roosevelt NP
sites.description: Rugged badlands where Teddy Roosevelt fell in love with conservation.

highlights.easy: 36-mile Scenic Loop with accessible pullouts and wildlife viewing.

seasonal.note: Bison and wild horses visible from the road. Painted Canyon overlook is stunning.

sites.name: Badlands NP
sites.description: Sharply eroded buttes and pinnacles ‚Äî one of Earth's great landscapes.

highlights.easy: Badlands Loop: 30 mi with 14 scenic overlooks. Short accessible trails.

seasonal.note: Combine with Mount Rushmore (1 hr away). Night sky program is excellent.

sites.name: Mount Rushmore NM
sites.description: Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt, and Lincoln carved in granite.

highlights.history: 14 years to carve. Borglum's tribute to American democracy.
highlights.easy: Presidential Trail: 0.6-mi paved. All viewing terraces accessible.

seasonal.note: Evening lighting ceremony summer nights. Parking fee ($10) not covered by pass.

sites.name: Harry S. Truman NHS
sites.description: Home of the 33rd President who ended WWII.

highlights.history: The president who made the hardest decisions of the 20th century.
highlights.easy: Visitor center accessible; guided home tours.

seasonal.note: Tours fill up ‚Äî arrive early or get tickets online.

sites.name: Kennesaw Mountain NBP
sites.description: 1864 Civil War battlefield from Sherman's Atlanta Campaign.

highlights.history: Three weeks of fighting. Well-preserved earthworks.
highlights.biking: 16 mi of trails including roads popular with cyclists.
highlights.easy: Drive to summit. Visitor center accessible.

seasonal.note: Very popular with local cyclists on weekends.

sites.name: New River Gorge NP
sites.description: America's newest NP (2020) ‚Äî dramatic gorge and whitewater.

highlights.fishing: Smallmouth bass in the New and Gauley Rivers.
highlights.biking: Road cycling routes along the gorge rim.
highlights.easy: Canyon Rim boardwalk with gorge overlooks.

seasonal.note: Bridge Day (3rd Sat in Oct) ‚Äî BASE jumpers from the New River Gorge Bridge.

sites.name: Lake Mead NRA
sites.description: Largest US reservoir ‚Äî Hoover Dam holds back the Colorado River.

highlights.fishing: Striped bass, largemouth bass, catfish ‚Äî great boat fishing.
highlights.easy: Scenic drives, accessible overlooks. Near Hoover Dam.

seasonal.note: Summer is extremely hot. Hoover Dam tours separate fee.

sites.name: Glen Canyon NRA
sites.description: Lake Powell ‚Äî 186 miles surrounded by red rock canyons.

highlights.fishing: Striped bass, smallmouth bass, walleye on the lake.
highlights.easy: Marinas accessible. Glen Canyon Dam overlook paved.

seasonal.note: Houseboat rentals available. Water levels have been recovering.

sites.name: Sleeping Bear Dunes NL
sites.description: Towering dunes on Lake Michigan ‚Äî voted 'Most Beautiful Place in America.'

highlights.biking: Heritage Trail: 22 mi paved through dunes, forest, and towns.
highlights.easy: Pierce Stocking Scenic Drive: 7.4 mi with stunning overlooks.

seasonal.note: Fall colors are spectacular. Cherry season in July.

sites.name: Cuyahoga Valley NP
sites.description: Winding river, waterfalls, and forests between Cleveland and Akron.

highlights.biking: Ohio & Erie Towpath: 20+ mi paved through the park.
highlights.easy: Brandywine Falls boardwalk. Scenic railroad rides.

seasonal.note: Cuyahoga Valley Scenic Railroad runs spring through fall.

sites.name: Lewis & Clark NHP
sites.description: Where Lewis and Clark reached the Pacific ‚Äî November 1805.

highlights.history: Fort Clatsop replica where the expedition wintered 1805‚Äì06.
highlights.easy: Fort and trails accessible; visitor center with exhibits.

seasonal.note: Living history demonstrations in summer. It rains a lot ‚Äî bring rain gear.

sites.name: Big Bend NP
sites.description: Remote desert where the Rio Grande carves dramatic canyons.

highlights.fishing: Catfish and bass in the Rio Grande.
highlights.easy: Ross Maxwell Drive: 30 mi to Santa Elena Canyon overlook.

seasonal.note: Summer is dangerously hot (110¬∞F+). Spring wildflowers can be incredible.
